nodes.label: Recursion
nodes.title: Recursion: A programming technique where a function calls itself in order to solve problems that can be broken down into smaller, similar subproblems.

nodes.label: Operations with Sets
nodes.title: Operations with Sets: Operations with Sets: Sets can undergo various operations, including union, intersection, difference, and complement, allowing for manipulation and comparison of sets.

nodes.label: Functions
nodes.title: Functions: Functions: Functions are mathematical constructs that relate elements of one set (the domain) to elements of another set (the codomain). They assign exactly one output to each input and are essential for modeling relationships between objects.

nodes.label: Morphisms
nodes.title: Morphisms: Morphisms: Morphisms are structure-preserving mappings between algebraic structures.

nodes.label: Python
nodes.title: Python: Python: High-level, interpreted, general-purpose programming language.

nodes.label: Iteratie of Recursie
nodes.title: Iteratie of Recursie: Iteratie of Recursie: Iteration (for loops) and recursion (calling functions within themselves) are common control flow mechanisms.

nodes.label: Haskell
nodes.title: Haskell: Haskell: A purely functional programming language known for its strong type system and lazy evaluation.

nodes.label: Functions
nodes.title: Functions: Functions: Fundamental building blocks for defining computations, often using pattern matching and recursion.

nodes.label: Working with lists
nodes.title: Working with lists: Working with lists: Various operations for efficient manipulation of lists, such as mapping, filtering, folding, and list comprehensions.

nodes.label: Functors
nodes.title: Functors: Functors: Types that can be mapped over, allowing for serialization of computations while preserving structure.
